In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Strategy 2020, the long-term strategic framework of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
underscores  the  importance  of  providing  knowledge  solutions  to  its  developing  member 
countries (DMCs).1 Alliances with regional and global research institutions are critical to ADB's 
knowledge  operations  and  are  a  key  part  of  the  Economics  and  Research  Department's 
medium-term priorities for 2010–2012. Such alliances will enable ADB to establish a wider 
research  network,  tap  a  larger  pool  of  talents  and  a  broader  range  of  expertise,  improve 
effectiveness and efficiency in producing quality knowledge products, enhance its capacity in 
providing  knowledge  solutions,  and  ultimately  raise  the  profile  of  ADB  as  a  knowledge 
institution. 
 
2.  The  proposed  research  and  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  aims  to  help 
establish research alliances between ADB and regional and global research institutions through 
collaborative studies on development issues that are critical to inclusive and environmentally 
sustainable growth and poverty eradication in developing Asia, both nationally and regionally. 
The TA will finance two studies: (i) rebalancing and sustaining growth in the People's Republic 
of  China  (PRC),  and  (ii) human  capital  development  in  developing  Asia.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework of the TA is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Rebalancing and sustaining growth in the People's Republic of China. While its 
rapid growth since the late 1970s has been impressive, the PRC faces serious challenges. First, 
the recent global imbalances and the outbreak of the global financial crisis in 2008 have raised 
questions about how long export-led growth can continue for an economy as large as the PRC. 
Second, rapid growth has increased household incomes across the board in the PRC and led to 
a  dramatic  reduction  in  extreme  poverty,  but  income  inequality  has  also  increased.  The 
widening gaps between urban and rural areas, and between eastern and western parts of the 
country, show the need to change the pattern of growth and make it more inclusive. Third, with 
per capita income now above $3,000, the PRC needs to find a way to sustain growth and avoid 
the "middle-income trap."3 Fourth, the country also faces environmental challenges. As one of 
the largest sources of carbon emissions in the world, it will have to deal with growing pressure 
to reduce emissions and move toward a low-carbon economy. 
 
4.  Rebalancing and sustaining growth, making growth more inclusive, and moving toward a 
low-carbon economy mean transforming the economic structure and exploring new sources of 
growth. This requires moving up the value chain in manufacturing, modernizing the services 
sector, expanding urbanization, developing small and medium-sized enterprises, and promoting 
low-carbon growth. Successful structural transformation needs to be supported by continued 
institutional development, policy reforms, and advancement of human capital. This includes 
improving the macroeconomic policy framework, reforming the finance sector, strengthening 
labor market institutions, upgrading the skills of the labor force, and instituting effective social 
policy and safety nets. Because the PRC is the third-largest economy and the largest exporter 
in  the  world,  understanding  and  managing  these  development  issues  is  vital  not  only  to

sustaining growth and improving living standards in the PRC, but also to supporting regional 
and global growth. 
 
5.  Despite  strong  interest  in  the  PRC  economy  and  a  growing  amount  of  literature, 
knowledge  gaps  still  exist,  especially  on  issues  such  as  rebalancing  growth,  low-carbon 
development, and avoiding the "middle-income trap." Although some issues, such as finance 
sector reform and social safety nets, have been studied extensively, changing circumstances 
and the new phase of development the PRC has entered dictate a fresh look. Research on 
these topics will not only inform the policy makers of the PRC, but also facilitate learning and 
knowledge sharing between the PRC and other DMCs. 
 
6.  Human capital development in developing Asia. Human capital plays an essential 
role in economic growth and poverty reduction. This could be explained through both micro and 
macro channels. From a macro perspective, accumulation of human capital improves labor 
productivity,  facilitates  technological  innovations,  increases  returns  on  capital,  and  makes 
growth more sustainable, which helps reduce poverty. From a micro perspective, education 
improves the chances of employment and better earnings. Education also helps improve a 
population's health outcomes such as life expectancy and infant mortality, while better health 
outcomes enhance returns to education. All in all, human capital development is important not 
only for its instrumental value, but also as a development goal in its own right.  
 
7.  Developing  Asian  countries  have  invested  significantly  in  education  and  health, 
contributing to the increase in the stock of human capital in recent decades.  However, much 
more needs to be done, especially in view of the region's growing population and the millions of 
people still living in poverty. Supporting human capital development in developing Asia requires 
a thorough understanding of key policy issues and constraints. These include (i) conceptual 
issues related to human capital; (ii) the political, social, and economic determinants; (iii) the 
levels and determinants of returns on investment in human capital; (iv) the link between human 
capital and economic growth and its inclusiveness, poverty reduction, institutional development, 
and  standards  of  living;  (v)  the  interaction  between  education  and  health;  and  (vi)  the 
interventions in human capital development that have (and have not) worked and why.  
 
8.  Despite the extensive literature on human capital development, significant knowledge 
gaps exist for developing Asia. Most literature looks at access to and financing of health and 
education services, but little work has been done on the quality of these services. To bridge this 
gap, the study will include a literature survey; an analysis of conceptual issues related to human 
capital development; and an analysis of the determinants of political, social, and economic 
factors  affecting  human  capital  development.  Ultimately,  the  study  aims  to  develop  policy 
recommendations for DMCs in human capital development. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be more evidence-based policy development in developing 
Asia in general, and the PRC in particular. 
 
10.  The outcome of the TA will be deeper understanding of key development challenges for 
developing Asia, particularly (i) the PRC's challenges and policy options in rebalancing its 
economy and making growth sustainable, and (ii) developing Asia's challenges, constraints, and 
policy options in human capital development.

3
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  In broad terms, the TA will produce and disseminate high-quality knowledge products, 
and  support  research  alliances  with  regional  and  global  research  institutions.  The  TA  will 
generate (i) research papers, reports, policy briefs, opinion pieces, and books; (ii) conferences, 
seminars, workshops, and media events to discuss and disseminate research findings; (iii) 
roundtable discussions with DMC officials and policy makers on research findings; and (iv) a 
project website to support knowledge sharing, dissemination, and networking.  
 
12.  Study 1: Rebalancing and sustaining the PRC's growth. The study will produce 
about  20  background  research  papers  and  a  synthesis  report  through  an  alliance  with  a 
development research institution in the PRC. Each background paper will (i) address a topic in 
the areas of structural transformation, new sources of growth, and institutional development and 
policy reforms needed to support structural transformation; and (ii) produce policy insights 
through a comprehensive literature survey, data analyses, reviews of international experiences, 
and diagnosis of critical constraints. Data used in the analyses could be publicly available, 
purchased, or obtained through original surveys. Independent reviewers will ensure quality 
control by providing critical comments on each paper at various stages. The synthesis report, 
which will be based on the background papers, will summarize significant findings and present 
policy options.    
 
13.  Key activities and deliverables include (i) an inception workshop to discuss and agree on 
methodological frameworks; (ii) a finalization workshop to discuss study results; (iii) roundtable 
discussions to disseminate the findings and policy messages to policy makers, academics and 
researchers in and outside the PRC, media, development partners, and other stakeholders; (iv) 
preparation of about 20 background papers; (v) preparation of a synthesis report; and (vi) 
publication of a book containing the major results of the background papers and synthesis 
report in English and Chinese. A tentative outline of the book is in Appendix 2. 
 
14.  Study 2: Human capital development in developing Asia. The study will produce 
background papers that (i) examine conceptual issues in human capital development, with 
emphasis on quality and rates of return on education; (ii) analyze links between human capital 
and economic growth and other socioeconomic variables; (iii) investigate the links between 
education, labor productivity, and utilization of human capital in explaining economic growth; (iv) 
provide a detailed analysis of the impacts of human capital development on people’s standard 
of living, focusing on policies that lead to improvement in the overall social welfare as well as its 
distribution; (v) explore the social, cultural, political, and economic processes that influence 
investment  in  human  capital;  (vi)  discuss  the  role  of  governments,  the  private  sector, 
households, and development partners in investing in human capital development; (vii) explore 
policy-relevant questions on whether to concentrate efforts and resources on basic education 
for all or on developing the skills of elite gifted students to spur economic growth; and (viii) 
assess  the  impact  and  effectiveness  of  specific  policy  interventions  in  human  capital 
development such as conditional cash transfer programs, with emphasis on the ability of the 
program to affect household investments, choices, and outcomes related to human capital 
development. Based on these background papers, a synthesis report will summarize significant 
findings and present policy options.    
 
15.  Key activities and deliverables include (i) an inception workshop to discuss and agree on 
methodological frameworks; (ii) a finalization workshop to discuss study results; (iii) roundtable 
discussions to disseminate major findings and policy messages to policy makers, academics

4   
and  researchers  in  and  outside  the  region,  media,  development  partners,  and  other 
stakeholders; (iv) preparation of background papers; and (v) preparation of a synthesis report.  
 
16.  Risks and assumptions. A key risk is that development agencies in participating DMCs 
may  not  be  fully  aware  of  the  research  findings  and  that  their  medium-  to  long-term 
development strategies would not benefit from the research findings. To mitigate this risk, the 
implementation  of  the  TA—including  the  design  and  conduct  of  individual  studies—will  be 
closely  coordinated  with  key  agencies  in  participating  DMCs  to  ensure  strong  ownership. 
Another potential risk is the emergence of a global or regional crisis that could shift the focus of 
development efforts away from medium- to long-term priorities and toward short-term initiatives 
to address the crisis. The main assumptions include the willingness of policy makers to base 
medium-  to  long-term  policies  on  empirical  evidence  gathered  through  research,  and  the 
availability of high-quality datasets in participating DMCs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost the equivalent of $1.1 million. It will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($930,000 from TASF—other sources and 
$170,000 from TASF-IV). Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. Within ADB, the TA will be implemented 
jointly by the Economic Analysis and Operations Support Division and the Office of the Chief 
Economist, in close coordination with concerned regional departments, particularly the East 
Asia Department, Southeast Asia Department, and South Asia Department.  
 
19.  For  study  1,  the  TA  will  use  the  single-source  selection  procedure  to  engage  the 
National School of Development (NSD) of Peking University for 30 person-months (national) to 
lead the work. Formerly known as the China Center for Economic Research, NSD has a large 
pool of development economists who are experienced in policy research and well published at 
home and abroad. The NSD is also well connected with government agencies responsible for 
development planning in the PRC, and with local academic institutions and think tanks. It has a 
large external collaboration program. Previous collaborations with ADB have confirmed the 
capability of NSD to undertake the proposed study.  
 
20.  NSD will form a study team that will be led by a representative from NSD and comprise 
development economists in the PRC, selected by NSD in consultation with ADB. Under the 
supervision of a steering committee (para. 25), the study team will (i) prepare background 
papers (in Chinese and English) on the selected topics agreed upon with ADB; (ii) draft the 
synthesis report jointly with ADB; (iii) organize the inception and finalization workshops in the 
PRC; (iv) be responsible for the publication of the study in Chinese according to an outline 
agreed  upon  with  ADB  and  assist  ADB  in  the  publication  of  the  English  version;  and  (v) 
participate in roundtable discussions to disseminate the study findings. ADB will also engage 
individual international experts for 6 person-months to supplement, under the supervision of 
ADB staff, the work by NSD.  
 
21.     In addition, study 1 will require 2 person-months of individual international consultant 
inputs for economics editing; 1 person-month of individual international resource person inputs 
for technical review of the study results and participation in the workshops as discussants; and

5
4 person-months  of  individual  national  consultant  inputs  for  copyediting  and  typesetting. 
Individual national consultants will be engaged as needed to provide research assistance.  
 
22.  For study 2, the TA will require 15 person-months of individual international consultant 
inputs to prepare the background papers and the synthesis report, participate in the inception 
and finalization workshops and dissemination activities, and assist in the publication of the study. 
In addition, the TA will require 2 person-months of individual international consultant inputs for 
economics  editing,  1  person-month  of  individual  international  resource  person  inputs  for 
technical review of the study results and participation in the workshops as discussants, and 
2 person-months  of  individual  national  consultant  inputs  for  copyediting  and  typesetting. 
Individual national consultants will be engaged as needed to provide research assistance. 
 
23.  Individual consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). National consultants working in 
ADB headquarters in Manila will be citizens of the Philippines. The terms of reference for the 
partner research institution for study 1, and individual consultants for study 1 and study 2, are in 
Appendix 4.  
 
24.  For each study, a steering committee will be created to provide strategic oversight, 
including  on  the  selection  of  research  topics.  The  steering  committee  for  study  1  will  be 
composed of the chief economist of ADB, an assistant chief economist of ADB, a representative 
of the East Asia Department, the dean of NSD, and the study team leader. The steering 
committee for study 2 will be composed of the chief economist of ADB; a representative of 
ADB's education community of practice; international experts in education, labor markets, and 
public policy; and the project team leader. Each steering committee will meet twice, once before 
the inception workshop and once before the finalization workshop.  
 
25.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook.4 
 
26.  The TA will begin in April 2010 and finish by May 2012. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
27.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,100,000 on a grant basis 
for Establishing Global Research Alliances, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

 OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Study 1: Rebalancing and Sustaining Growth in the People's Republic of China  
 
1.  International Consultants 
1.  Technical  experts  (international,  6  person-months).  A  team  of  individual  technical 
experts  will  be  engaged  for  6  person-months  to  study  topics  related  to  rebalancing  and 
sustaining growth in the People's Republic of China.  The topics will be identified by the Asian 
Development Bank in consultation with the partner research institution. The experts will be 
economists with well-established research records on the economy of the People's Republic of 
China (PRC) in general and the study topics in particular. Under the supervision of ADB staff, 
the experts will  
(i)  prepare background and analytical papers on the topics assigned by ADB staff, 
(ii)  present research findings and participate actively in the two workshops, 
(iii)  revise and finalize the papers for publication, 
(iv)  review and provide comments on the papers prepared by the study team, and 
(v)  assist ADB and the partner institute in disseminating research outcomes of the 
technical assistance (TA). 
 
2.  The experts will report to the assigned ADB staff and will prepare progress reports. 
3.  Resource  persons  (international,  1  person-month).  Resource  persons  with 
backgrounds as policy makers and/or experts will be engaged to review the draft background 
papers and the book, and to participate in the workshops. 
 
4.  Economics editor (international, 2 person-months). An economics editor with extensive 
experience  in  editing  economic  publications  will  be  engaged  to  ensure  a  high  quality  of 
publications. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the editor will 
(i)  review the draft papers and suggest revisions to ensure the chapters form a 
consistent report; 
(ii)  assist in integrating the overall findings and in reflecting these in the overview 
chapter of the book; and 
(iii)  ensure that edited materials adhere to ADB style and usage, conform to high 
publication standards, and are properly and timely delivered. 
 
2.  National Consultants 
5.  Partner  research  institution  (national,  30  person-months).  An  economic  research 
institution  (partner  institution)  with  well-known  expertise  in  the  economic  and  development 
issues of the PRC will be engaged to organize and coordinate the preparation, publication, and 
dissemination of research outputs. In consultation with ADB, the partner institution will create a 
study team of internationally renowned PRC economists familiar with study-related issues, and 
engage experts from outside the institution to serve as discussants. 
 
6.  The study team will be headed by a team leader with local and international experience. 
Under the supervision of the steering committee, and in close coordination with ADB staff in the 
Economics  and  Research  Department,  the  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  the  overall 
administration and management of the study, including 
(i)  finalizing, jointly with ADB staff, the study topics;

(x)  updating ADB staff regularly on the progress of various activities; and

7.  Under the supervision of the team leader, the study team will 
(i)  prepare  literature  and  policy  reviews  and  research  outlines  in  English  and 
Chinese before the inception workshop; 
(ii)  participate and present in the inception workshop, and revise the literature and

before the finalization workshop in English and Chinese; 
(iv)  participate and present in the finalization workshop, and revise the background

(v)  finalize the background research papers in English and Chinese; and 
(vi)  contribute to the synthesis report and book publication as needed.  
 
8.  Copy editor and typesetter (national, 4 person-months). A copy editor will be engaged 
for 2 person-months once all the components of the book are completed to ensure that edited 
materials adhere to ADB style and usage, and conform to high publication standards. In addition, 
a typesetter will be engaged for 2 person-months to lay out the text, tables, and charts, and to 
convert the files into the required format for publication. The consultants should have expertise 
in copyediting and desktop publishing, and preferably have extensive experience in similar 
assignments involving preparation of economic publications. 
 
9.  Research assistants (national, 16 person-months). A number of research assistants 
with background in economics and with strong analytical skills will be engaged as needed to 
support the study. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the research assistants will assist in 
(i)  collecting and analyzing study-related data, 
(ii)  setting up and updating the study website, and 
(iii)  preparing presentations and publications.

12  Appendix 4 
 
B.  Study 2:  Human Capital Development in Developing Asia 
 
1.  International Consultants 
 
10.  Human  capital  development  experts (international, 15 person-months). A team of 
human capital development experts will be engaged for 15 person-months to study issues 
identified by the steering committee for study 2. The experts will be economists with well-
established records on development economics research in general and the study topic in 
particular. Under the supervision of the steering committee and in close coordination with ADB 
staff, the experts will 
(i)  prepare background and analytical papers on the topics assigned by ADB staff, 
(ii)  present research findings and participate actively in the two workshops, 
(iii)  revise and finalize the papers for publication, 
(iv)  review and provide comments on the papers prepared by the other experts, and 
(v)  assist ADB in disseminating research outputs. 
 
11.  The experts will report to ADB staff in the Economics and Research Department and will 
prepare progress reports. 
 
12.  Resource  persons  (international,  1  person-month).  Resource  persons  with 
backgrounds as policy makers and/or experts will be engaged to review the draft background 
papers and the final report, and to participate as members of the steering committee and in the 
workshops. 
 
13.  Economics editor (international, 2 person-months). An economics editor with extensive 
experience in editing economic publications will be engaged to ensure the high quality of 
publications. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the editor will 
(i)  review the draft papers and suggest revisions to ensure the chapters form a 
consistent report; 
(ii)  assist in integrating the overall findings and in reflecting these in the overview 
chapter of the final report; and 
(iii)  ensure that edited materials adhere to ADB style and usage, conform to high 
publication standards, and are delivered properly and on time. 
 
2.  National Consultants 
 
14.  Copy editor and typesetter (national, 2 person-months). A copy editor will be engaged 
for 1 person-month once all the components of the reports and papers are completed to ensure 
that edited materials adhere to ADB style and usage, and conform to high publication standards. 
In addition, a typesetter will be engaged for 1 person-month to lay out the text, tables, and 
charts, and to convert the files into the required format for publication. The consultants should 
have expertise in copyediting and desktop publishing, and preferably have extensive experience 
in similar assignments involving preparation of economic publications. 
 
15.  Research assistants (national, 16 person-months). A number of research assistants 
with background in economics and with strong analytical skills will be engaged as needed to 
support the study. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the research assistants will assist in 
(i)  collecting and analyzing study-related data, 
(ii)  setting up and updating the study website, and 
(iii)  preparing presentations and publications.
